physical_appearance:This is a batik kain panjang.  It features pairs of phoenixes with outstretched wings
 set against a background of flowering tendrils and rock forms. The background is further embellished with filler motifs to create an intricate and dense design. There is a signature on the bottom-right of the batik kain panjang.
subject_terms_1:Peranakan phoenixes foliage (motif) scrolls (motif)
subject_terms_2:Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
subject_terms_3:Batik Peranakan costumes
sgcool_label_text:Pairs of phonexies with outstretched wings are set against a blue background of flowering tendrils and rock forms.  Intricate filler motifs known as isen-isen enliven the overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan 100% Tulis”.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang.  It features pairs of phoenixes with outstretched wings, set against a background of flowering tendrils and rock forms. The background is further embellished with filler motifs to create an intricate and dense design. There is a signature on the bottom-right of the batik kain panjang.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Pairs of phonexies with outstretched wings are set against a blue background of flowering tendrils and rock forms.  Intricate filler motifs known as isen-isen enliven the overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan 100% Tulis”.
